comments:
Build ID: 3.3RC1-200705171700

Steps To Reproduce:
Using the snippet below we can produce SWTError: no more handles on Windows XP SP2 (Hungarian version). Modifying the CASE constant value we can produce three different results: no more handles error, not visible sash and 'normal' behaviour:

import org.eclipse.swt.SWT;
import org.eclipse.swt.custom.SashForm;
import org.eclipse.swt.layout.FillLayout;
import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Composite;
import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display;
import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Shell;

public class Test
{
	/**
	 * 0 - crashes (SWTError: No more handles)
	 * 1 - no crash but sash not visible
	 * 2 - works fine
	 */
	private static final int CASE = 0;
	
	public static void main(String[] args)
	{
		final Shell shell = new Shell();
		shell.setLayout(new FillLayout());
		
		if (CASE == 2)
		{
			shell.open();
		}
		
		Composite parent = shell;
		
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		
		if (CASE == 1 || CASE == 2)
		{
			// Add another level to make it no crash
			parent = createComposite(parent);
			
			if (CASE == 2)
			{
				// And another level to make it work :)
				parent = createComposite(parent);
			}
		}
		
		parent = createComposite(parent);
		parent = createSashForm(parent);
		createBorderComposite(parent);
		createBorderComposite(parent);
		
		if (CASE == 0 || CASE == 1)
		{
			shell.open();
		}
		else
		{
			shell.layout(true, true);
		}
		
		Display display = shell.getDisplay();
		while (!shell.isDisposed())
		{
			if (!display.readAndDispatch())
			{
				display.sleep();
			}
		}
	}
	
	private static Composite createSashForm(Composite parent)
	{
		SashForm form = new SashForm(parent, 0);
		return form;
	}
	
	private static Composite createBorderComposite(Composite parent)
	{
		return new Composite(parent, SWT.BORDER);
	}
	
	private static Composite createComposite(Composite parent)
	{
		Composite ret = new Composite(parent, 0);
		ret.setLayout(new FillLayout());
		return ret;
	}
}
 

The SWTError we got:
Exception in thread "main" org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: No more handles

	at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3297)

More information:

We have developed a moderate-size gui application (with many hundreds of Controls) and at certain states the application produces "no more handles" errors.

First we checked that the problem is not related to the maximum number of handles; the code snippet was developed as a result of narrowing the original code to the bare minimum to show the problem. It seems that the behaviour is change when you add / remove some Composite.

We reproduced the problem with SWT 3.2.2 and 3.3RC1 as well, but the behaviour was different on Windows XP and Windows 2000 (no more handles occured on 'different levels'). So we created a modified SWT 3.3RC1 where we printed out GetLastError value on CreateWindowEx native function calls and it seemed that there is no error (GetLastError returned 0) but the returned handle is 0 as well. It seems to be an operating system-specific issue... but it is very strange.
What can I tell you?  A native operating system faces that same limition.  Do you really need to create that many controls in your application?
Sorry but WONTFIX.  This is an operating system limitation that we can't change and that every native program on the desktop shares.

I saw some other bug reports where there are discussions about operating system limitations (like bug 178024).

The interesting about this one (and that's why I open a new report instead of commenting the above) that actually the snippet can eliminate the "no more handles" error with _adding_ more layers...

In our application the original behaviour is much more interesting (and annoying). We had a CTabFolder somewhere in the gui and some SashForm-s on the tab items. If we make the second tab to be shown after creating the components we got the error constantly (and it  always comes from SashFormLayout.layout). But if we want to make the first tab everything is OK - with the absolutely same layout and number of controls. So we found our work-around and we are happy :).

I agree with you - we also think that this annoyance is most probably an operating system issue. And I absolutely understand the reason of the WONTFIX resolution. But - according to the above - it does not seem to be related with any limitation (number of controls, number of layers etc)...

Keep up the good work. SWT is a very good quality library.
